Read April 6. 1815. 10
X X. On <s>the<\s> some phenomena of <s>prismatic<\s> colours,
exhibited by thin plates. By John Knox, Esq. Communicated 
by Thomas Young, M.D. For. Sec. R.S.
It is not without reason that the phenomena of Light 
have been subjects of speculative enquirey from the 
earliest ages of philosophy; since perhaps no study can 
be more interesting to the inquisitive mind, than the 
contemplation of that Element from which it derives 
its most exalted enjoyments.
There are probably no appearances in Physical Opticks 
that have excited more attention, or that have been less 
satisfactorily accounted for, than those prismatic concentric 
Rings which appear between Lenses, or between a flat gap of a lens, when laid together. And notwithstanding some 
of the most eminent philosophers and Opticians of the 
Age, have given explanations thereof; particularly Sir 
Isaac Newton & Dr. Herschell, it will appear from what 
follows, that the subject is far from being exhausted. 
The insufficiency of Newtons theory for the solution 
of this problem, by the suppositious fits of easy transmission and
reflection of the Rays of Light, is now generally admitted; 
nor does it appear that any other more satisfactory, has 
yet been adopted in its stead.
This will not be thought surprising, if it shall 
appear by the following experiments, that neither 
Newton, nor any other writer that has followed him 
in the same line, has been in possession of all the 
phenomena connected with this curious and intricate subject.
<s>Sir Isaac Newton's Hypothesis, as published in his Book 
on Opticks, is briefly as follows. 
"Every Ray of Light in its passage through any refracting 
surface, is put into a certain transient constitution or state, 
which in the progress of the Ray, returns at equal intervals, 
& departs the Ray at every return to be easily trans-
